situations.text:
The Spanish conquest of Peru was one of the most important campaigns in the Spanish colonization of the Americas. After years of preliminary exploration and military skirmishes, 168 Spanish soldiers under conquistador Francisco Pizarro, his brothers, and their native allies captured the Sapa Inca Atahualpa in the 1532 Battle of Cajamarca. It was the first step in a long campaign that took decades of fighting but ended in Spanish victory in 1572 and colonization of the region as the Viceroyalty of Peru. The conquest of the Inca Empire (called 'Tahuantinsuyu' or 'Tawantinsuyu' in Quechua, meaning 'Realm of the Four Parts'), led to spin-off campaigns into present-day Chile and Colombia, as well as expeditions towards the Amazon Basin.
When the Spanish arrived at the borders of the Inca Empire in 1528, it spanned a considerable area and was by far the largest of the four grand pre-Columbian civilizations. Extending southward from the Ancomayo, which is now known as the Patía River, in southern present-day Colombia to the Maule River in what would later be known as Chile, and eastward from the Pacific Ocean to the edge of the Amazonian jungles, the empire covered some of the most mountainous terrain on Earth. In less than a century, the Inca had expanded their empire from about 400,000 km2 (150,000 sq mi) in 1448 to 1,800,000 km2 (690,000 sq mi) in 1528, just before the arrival of the Spanish. This vast area of land varied greatly in cultures and in climate. Because of the diverse cultures and geography, the Inca allowed many areas of the empire to be governed under the control of local leaders, who were watched and monitored by Inca officials. Under the administrative mechanisms established by the Inca, all parts of the empire answered to, and were ultimately under the direct control of, the Emperor. Scholars estimate that the population of the Inca Empire was more than 16,000,000.
Some scholars, such as Jared Diamond, believe that while the Spanish conquest was undoubtedly the proximate cause of the collapse of the Inca Empire, it may very well have been past its peak and already in the process of decline. In 1528, Emperor Huayna Capac ruled the Inca Empire. He could trace his lineage back to a 'stranger king' named Manco Cápac, the mythical founder of the Inca clan, who according to tradition emerged from a cave in a region called Paqariq Tampu.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_conquest_of_Peru

questions.text: The Spanish Conquest of Peru led to the discovery of the Amazon Basin
questions.explanation: All that is stated is that the conquest of the Inca Empire led to “expeditions towards the Amazon Basin”, however we do not know if the conquest led to the discovery of it (it could have been discovered beforehand). Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.text: The Spanish Conquest of Peru took 40 years
questions.explanation: The time between 1572 and 1532 is 40 years – the time between the “first step of the long campaign” and the fighting that “ended in Spanish victory in 1572”. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: The Inca empire expanded by more than 4 times in an 80 year period
questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph, it states that the Inca had expanded their empire from about 400,000 to 1,800,000 square km, which is more than 4 times bigger than 400,000. The time period between these two measurements is 80 years (1448-1528). Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: The Spanish Conquest was unequivocally the cause of the collapse of the Inca Empire
questions.explanation: In the 3rd paragraph, it states that “some scholars, such as Jared Diamond, believe that… the Spanish conquest was undoubtedly the proximate cause of the collapse of the Inca Empire”, however, only “some scholars” believe this. Therefore, it cannot be an unequivocal opinion because not everyone thinks the same (it may be “undoubtedly” amongst these “some scholars”, but not all). Therefore, the answer is C.

The Roman Empire was the post-Republican period of ancient Rome. As a polity it included large territorial holdings around the Mediterranean Sea in Europe, North Africa and West Asia ruled by emperors. From the accession of Caesar Augustus to the military anarchy of the third century, it was a principate with Italy as metropole of the provinces and its city of Rome as sole capital (27 BC – 286 AD). Although fragmented briefly during the military crisis, the empire was forcibly reassembled, then ruled by multiple emperors who shared rule over the Western Roman Empire (based in Milan and later in Ravenna) and over the Eastern Roman Empire (based in Nicomedia and later in Constantinople). Rome remained the nominal capital of both parts until 476 AD, when it sent the imperial insignia to Constantinople following the capture of Ravenna by the barbarians of Odoacer and the subsequent deposition of Romulus Augustus. The fall of the Western Roman Empire to Germanic kings, along with the hellenization of the Eastern Roman Empire into the Byzantine Empire, conventionally marks the end of Ancient Rome and the beginning of the Middle Ages.
The predecessor state of the Roman Empire, the Roman Republic (which had replaced Rome's monarchy in the 6th century BC) became severely destabilized in a series of civil wars and political conflicts. In the mid-1st century BC Julius Caesar was appointed as perpetual dictator and then assassinated in 44 BC. Civil wars and proscriptions continued, culminating in the victory of Octavian over Mark Antony and Cleopatra at the Battle of Actium in 31 BC. The following year Octavian conquered Ptolemaic Egypt, ending the Hellenistic period that had begun with the conquests of Alexander the Great of Macedon in the 4th century BC. Octavian's power then became unassailable, and in 27 BC the Roman Senate formally granted him overarching power and the new title Augustus, effectively making him the first Roman emperor.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Empire

questions.text: Rome was always the capital of the Roman Empire
questions.explanation: In the 1st paragraph, it states that “Rome remained the nominal capital of both parts until 476 AD, when it sent the imperial insignia to Constantinople”. In addition, prior to this the passage states that Rome was the “sole capital” from 27 BC to 286 AD – therefore using these two statements we know that Rome stopped being the capital in 286 AD, and Constantinople likely became the capital after 476 AD. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: Ancient Rome and the Middle Ages are both classified as time periods in history
questions.explanation: The first line of the passage states that “The Roman Empire was the post-Republican period of ancient Rome”. From this we can tell that ancient Rome was a period of time. At the end of the 1st paragraph, it states that the fall of the Western Roman Empire “marks the end of Ancient Rome and the beginning of the Middle Ages”. Given we know ancient Rome is a time period, we can infer that the Middle Ages is too. Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: If not for Julius Caesar’s assassination, he would have remained as dictator forever
questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph it states that “Julius Caesar was appointed as perpetual dictator” – meaning he would have been there forever if he was not killed (perpetual = enduring forever, like a perpetuity in finance). Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.text: Julius Caesar was the first official Roman emperor
questions.explanation: The first official emperor was Octavian, as the last line in the passage states how he was effectively made “the first Roman emperor”. Therefore, the answer is B.

Gaius Julius Caesar, better known by his nomen gentilicium and cognomen Julius Caesar, was a Roman dictator, politician, and military general who played a critical role in the events that led to the demise of the Roman Republic and the rise of the Roman Empire. He was also a historian and wrote Latin prose.
In 60 BC, Caesar, Crassus and Pompey formed the First Triumvirate, a political alliance that dominated Roman politics for several years. Their attempts to amass power as Populares were opposed by the Optimates within the Roman Senate, among them Cato the Younger with the frequent support of Cicero. Caesar rose to become one of the most powerful politicians in the Roman Republic through a number of his accomplishments, notably his victories in the Gallic Wars, completed by 51 BC. During this time, Caesar became the first Roman general to cross both the English Channel and the Rhine River, when he built a bridge across the Rhine and crossed the Channel to invade Britain. Caesar's wars extended Rome's territory to Britain and past Gaul. These achievements granted him unmatched military power and threatened to eclipse the standing of Pompey, who had realigned himself with the Senate after the death of Crassus in 53 BC. With the Gallic Wars concluded, the Senate ordered Caesar to step down from his military command and return to Rome. Leaving his command in Gaul meant losing his immunity from being charged as a criminal for waging unsanctioned wars. As a result, Caesar found himself with no other options but to cross the Rubicon with the 13th Legion in 49 BC, leaving his province and illegally entering Roman Italy under arms. This began Caesar's civil war, and his victory in the war by 45 BC put him in an unrivaled position of power and influence.
After assuming control of government, Caesar began a program of social and governmental reforms, including the creation of the Julian calendar. He gave citizenship to many residents of far regions of the Roman Republic. He initiated land reform and support for veterans. His populist and authoritarian reforms angered the elites, who began to conspire against him. On the Ides of March (15 March), 44 BC, Caesar was assassinated by a group of rebellious senators led by Gaius Cassius Longinus, Marcus Junius Brutus and Decimus Junius Brutus, who stabbed him to death.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julius_Caesar

questions.explanation: There is no information to indicate whether he was the MOST powerful military figure in Roman history, and no comparison to others to determine this either. Therefore, the answer is C.

All we know is that he could have ben charged. Therefore, the answer is C.

Therefore, it can be inferred that they are the ones who assassinated him, as the passage immediately goes on to detail the killing of him by “rebellious senators”. Therefore we know it was his “populist and authoritarian reforms” not progressive reforms that led to his death. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.explanation: Throughout the passage we see Caesar has been involved in the military, and in politics after “assuming control of government”, and in arts as he was a “historian and wrote Latin prose” (1st paragraph). Therefore, the answer is A.

The Battle of Hastings was fought on 14 October 1066 between the Norman-French army of William, the Duke of Normandy, and an English army under the Anglo-Saxon King Harold Godwinson, beginning the Norman conquest of England. It took place approximately 7 miles (11 kilometres) northwest of Hastings, close to the present-day town of Battle, East Sussex, and was a decisive Norman victory.
The background to the battle was the death of the childless King Edward the Confessor in January 1066, which set up a succession struggle between several claimants to his throne. Harold was crowned king shortly after Edward's death, but faced invasions by William, his own brother Tostig, and the Norwegian King Harald Hardrada (Harold III of Norway). Hardrada and Tostig defeated a hastily gathered army of Englishmen at the Battle of Fulford on 20 September 1066, and were in turn defeated by Harold at the Battle of Stamford Bridge five days later. The deaths of Tostig and Hardrada at Stamford Bridge left William as Harold's only serious opponent. While Harold and his forces were recovering, William landed his invasion forces in the south of England at Pevensey on 28 September 1066 and established a beachhead for his conquest of the kingdom. Harold was forced to march south swiftly, gathering forces as he went.
The exact numbers present at the battle are unknown; modern estimates are around 10,000 for William and about 7,000 for Harold. The composition of the forces is clearer; the English army was composed almost entirely of infantry and had few archers, whereas only about half of the invading force was infantry, the rest split equally between cavalry and archers. Harold appears to have tried to surprise William, but scouts found his army and reported its arrival to William, who marched from Hastings to the battlefield to confront Harold. The battle lasted from about 9 am to dusk. Early efforts of the invaders to break the English battle lines had little effect; therefore, the Normans adopted the novel tactic of pretending to flee in panic and then turning on their pursuers. Harold's death, probably near the end of the battle, led to the retreat and defeat of most of his army. After further marching and some skirmishes, William was crowned as king on Christmas Day 1066.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings

questions.text: The Battle of Hastings was entitled as such because it was fought in Hastings
questions.explanation: Although we know that the battle “took place approximately 7 miles northwest of Hastings” (1st paragraph), and therefore we know the battle was NOT fought in Hastings, the question is actually asking whether that was the REASON it was called the Battle of Hastings. We have no information on why the battle was called the Battle of Hastings, so therefore we cannot tell the reason why it was entitled as such. Therefore, the answer is C. (Note: carefully read what the question is actually asking you to figure out).

You might assume it, but remember we can’t make any assumptions. Furthermore, it states that there was a “succession struggle between several claimants to his throne” so that adds to the lack of clarity regarding who was the true heir. Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.explanation: The 3rd paragraph states that “the exact numbers present at the battle are unknown” – therefore it cannot be well-known that Harold’s army was far less than William’s. Since ‘unknown’ and ‘well-known’ are contradicting each other, the answer is B, false.

questions.explanation: In the 3rd paragraph the passage states that “the Normans adopted the novel tactic of …” – the word novel highlights that this tactic is new, so it can be inferred that this tactic was not seen before by the opposition. Therefore, the answer is A.

The Iraq War was a protracted armed conflict that began in 2003 with the invasion of Iraq by a United States-led coalition that overthrew the government of Saddam Hussein. The conflict continued for much of the next decade as an insurgency emerged to oppose the occupying forces and the post-invasion Iraqi government. An estimated 151,000 to 600,000 Iraqis were killed in the first three to four years of conflict. US troops were officially withdrawn in 2009 but are still fighting in Iraq, most of them having been redeployed following the spread of the Syrian Civil War and the territorial gains of the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant. Many former soldiers are employed by defence contractors and private military companies. The U.S. became re-involved in 2014 at the head of a new coalition; the insurgency and many dimensions of the civil armed conflict continue. The invasion occurred as part of the George W. Bush administration's War on Terror, following the September 11 attacks.
In October 2002, Congress authorized President Bush to use military force against Iraq should he choose to. The Iraq War began on 20 March 2003, when the U.S., joined by the U.K. and several coalition allies, launched a 'shock and awe' bombing campaign. Iraqi forces were quickly overwhelmed as U.S.-led forces swept through the country. The invasion led to the collapse of the Ba'athist government; Saddam Hussein was captured during Operation Red Dawn in December of that same year and executed three years later. The power vacuum following Saddam's demise and the mismanagement of the Coalition Provisional Authority led to widespread civil war between Shias and Sunnis, as well as a lengthy insurgency against coalition forces. Many of the violent insurgent groups were supported by Iran and al-Qaeda in Iraq. The United States responded with a build-up of 170,000 troops in 2007. This build-up gave greater control to Iraq's government and military, and was judged a success by many. The winding down of U.S. involvement in Iraq accelerated under President Barack Obama. The U.S. formally withdrew all combat troops from Iraq by December 2011.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraq_War

questions.text: The number of Iraqis killed during the initial years of the conflict is unknown

Therefore, the answer is A.

The passage could have said “following Christmas of 2001”, but that doesn’t mean that Christmas was the cause of the invasion, merely just an indicator of time. Therefore, the answer is C.

Therefore we can infer that the actions of the coalition in removing Saddam led to instability in the form of the civil war. Therefore, the answer is A.

This build-up gave greater control to Iraq’s government…”. Therefore, we know that whilst they fought against the government before, at this point they are clearly helping the Iraq government. Therefore, the answer is B.

Penguins for the most part breed in large colonies, the exceptions being the yellow-eyed and Fiordland species; these colonies may range in size from as few as a 100 pairs for gentoo penguins, to several hundred thousand in the case of king, macaroni and chinstrap penguins. Living in colonies results in a high level of social interaction between birds, which has led to a large repertoire of visual as well as vocal displays in all penguin species. Agonistic displays are those intended to confront or drive off, or alternately appease and avoid conflict with, other individuals.
Penguins form monogamous pairs for a breeding season, though the rate the same pair recouples varies drastically. Most penguins lay two eggs in a clutch, although the two largest species, the emperor and the king penguins, lay only one. With the exception of the emperor penguin, where the male does it all, all penguins share the incubation duties. These incubation shifts can last days and even weeks as one member of the pair feeds at sea.
Penguins generally only lay one brood; the exception is the little penguin, which can raise two or three broods in a season.
Penguin eggs are smaller than any other bird species when compared proportionally to the weight of the parent birds; at 52 g (2 oz), the little penguin egg is 4.7% of its mothers' weight, and the 450 g (1 lb) emperor penguin egg is 2.3%.The relatively thick shell forms between 10 and 16% of the weight of a penguin egg, presumably to reduce the effects of dehydration and to minimize the risk of breakage in an adverse nesting environment. The yolk, too, is large, and comprises 22–31% of the egg. Some yolk often remains when a chick is born, and is thought to help sustain the chick if the parents are delayed in returning with food.
When emperor penguin mothers lose a chick, they sometimes attempt to 'steal' another mother's chick, usually unsuccessfully as other females in the vicinity assist the defending mother in keeping her chick.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penguin

Without knowing the meaning of agonistic, you can infer that the agonistic displays are referring to the previously mentioned visual and vocal displays (bodies and noises). Therefore, the answer is A.

questions.explanation: In the 4th paragraph, we see that the emperor penguin egg is 2.3% of the mother’s weight, and the egg weights 450g. Thus, 0.023*x = 450g, where x = mother’s weight. Therefore, x = 0.450kg/0.023 = 19.5…kg. Therefore, the answer is A.

The statement does not imply or state that this is the only time this behaviour occurs. That is why the answer is not B, false, but rather C, can’t tell.

Dolphin is a common name for aquatic mammals within the infraorder Cetacea. The term dolphin usually refers to the extant families Delphinidae (the oceanic dolphins), Platanistidae (the Indian river dolphins), Iniidae (the New World river dolphins), and Pontoporiidae (the brackish dolphins), and the extinct Lipotidae (baiji or Chinese river dolphin). There are 40 extant species named as dolphins.
Dolphins range in size from the 1.7 m (5.6 ft) long and 50 kg (110 lb) Maui's dolphin to the 9.5 m (31 ft) and 10 t (11 short tons) killer whale. Several species exhibit sexual dimorphism, in that the males are larger than females. They have streamlined bodies and two limbs that are modified into flippers. Though not quite as flexible as seals, some dolphins can travel at 55.5 km/h (34.5 mph) as a result. Dolphins use their conical shaped teeth to capture fast moving prey. They have well-developed hearing which is adapted for both air and water and is so well developed that some can survive even if they are blind. Some species are well adapted for diving to great depths. They have a layer of fat, or blubber, under the skin to keep warm in the cold water.
Although dolphins are widespread, most species prefer the warmer waters of the tropic zones, but some, like the right whale dolphin, prefer colder climates. Dolphins feed largely on fish and squid, but a few, like the killer whale, feed on large mammals, like seals. Male dolphins typically mate with multiple females every year, but females only mate every two to three years. Calves are typically born in the spring and summer months and females bear all the responsibility for raising them. Mothers of some species fast and nurse their young for a relatively long period of time. Dolphins produce a variety of vocalizations, usually in the form of clicks and whistles.
Dolphins are sometimes hunted in places such as Japan, in an activity known as dolphin drive hunting. Besides drive hunting, they also face threats from bycatch, habitat loss, and marine pollution. Dolphins have been depicted in various cultures worldwide. Dolphins occasionally feature in literature and film, as in the film series Free Willy. Dolphins are sometimes kept in captivity and trained to perform tricks. The most common dolphin species in captivity is the bottlenose dolphin, while there are around 60 captive killer whales.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolphin

Therefore we do not know if there are ONLY 5 extant families. Therefore, the answer is A. The reason B is not the correct answer is that the passage states that “there are 40 extant species names as dolphins”, so we know there are AT LEAST 40 (there could be more but we don’t know and the passage does not mention whether these are the ONLY species).

The Great Leap Forward (Second Five Year Plan) of the People's Republic of China (PRC) was an economic and social campaign by the Communist Party of China (CPC) from 1958 to 1962. Chairman Mao Zedong launched the campaign to reconstruct the country from an agrarian economy into a communist society through the formation of people's communes. Mao decreed increased effort to multiply grain yields and industry should be brought to the countryside. Local officials were fearful of Anti-Rightist Campaigns and competed to fulfill or over-fulfill quotas based on Mao's exaggerated claims. They collected 'surpluses' that in fact did not exist, leaving farmers to starve. Higher officials did not dare to report the economic disaster caused by these policies, and national officials blamed bad weather for the decline in food output and took little or no action. The Great Leap resulted in tens of millions of deaths. A lower-end estimate is 18 million and upper estimates find that some 45 million people died. About the same number of births were lost or postponed, making the Great Chinese Famine the largest in human history.
Chief changes in the lives of rural Chinese people included the incremental introduction of mandatory agricultural collectivization. Private farming was prohibited, and those engaged in it were persecuted and labeled counter-revolutionaries. Restrictions on rural people were enforced through public struggle sessions and social pressure, although people also experienced forced labor. Rural industrialization, officially a priority of the campaign, saw 'its development ... aborted by the mistakes of the Great Leap Forward.' The Great Leap was one of two periods between 1953 and 1976 in which China's economy shrank. Economist Dwight Perkins argues that enormous amounts of investment produced only modest increases in production or none at all. ... In short, the Great Leap was a very expensive disaster.
In 1959, Mao Zedong ceded day-to-day leadership to pragmatic moderates like Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping and the CPC studied the damage done at conferences in 1960 and 1962. Mao did not retreat from his policies but blamed problems on bad implementation and rightists for opposing him. He initiated the Cultural Revolution in 1966 in order to remove this opposition and re-consolidate his power.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Leap_Forward

The financial catastrophe is mentioned throughout, for example in the 1st paragraph, “higher officials do not dare to report the economic disaster caused by these policies”. Although the Anti-Rightist campaigns are mentioned, they are not attributed as an effect of the Great Leap Forward, rather more like a policy. Therefore, the answer is C.

Therefore we can infer that Liu and Deng were his opposition and Mao did not want to lose his power. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: In addition to persecution, people who chose to farm privately were admonished through
questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph it states that “private farming was prohibited, and those engaged in it were persecuted and labelled counter-revolutionaries”. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.explanation: Although the passage does not state this directly, of the four options, C is the best as the main component given in the passage of the Great Leap Forward’s failure is that it was an economic disaster. Of the 4 options, option C directly links the collection of surpluses that “did not exist” to the starvation of farmers and the “economic disaster” caused by these policies. Therefore, the answer is C.

The Cultural Revolution, formally the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, was a sociopolitical movement in the People's Republic of China from 1966 until 1976. Launched by Mao Zedong, then Chairman of the Communist Party of China (CPC), its stated goal was to preserve Chinese Communism by purging remnants of capitalist and traditional elements from Chinese society, and to re-impose Mao Zedong Thought (known outside China as Maoism) as the dominant ideology in the CPC.
Mao launched the movement in May 1966, soon calling on young people to bombard the headquarters and proclaiming that 'to rebel is justified'. Mao charged that bourgeois elements had infiltrated the government and society and that they aimed to restore capitalism. Lin Biao, head of the People's Liberation Army (PLA), was written into the constitution as Mao's successor; Lin had compiled the Little Red Book, a selection of Mao's sayings, that became a sacred text for Mao's personality cult. To eliminate his rivals within the CPC and in schools, factories, and government institutions, Mao insisted that revisionists be removed through violent class struggle. China's youth responded by forming Red Guard groups around the country, which split into rival factions and sometimes open battle. Schools and universities were closed. Urban workers likewise split into factions, and the PLA had to be sent to restore order. Senior officials, most notably Liu Shaoqi and Deng Xiaoping, were purged or exiled. Millions were accused of being Rightists and persecuted or suffered public humiliation, imprisonment, torture, hard labor, seizure of property, and sometimes execution or harassment into suicide. Many urban intellectual youths were sent to the countryside in the Down to the Countryside Movement. Red Guards destroyed historical relics and artifacts and ransacked cultural and religious sites.
Mao officially declared the end of the Cultural Revolution in 1969, but its active phase lasted until at least 1971, when Lin Biao fled and died in a plane crash, accused of a botched coup against Mao. After Mao's death and the arrest of the Gang of Four in 1976, Deng Xiaoping gradually dismantled the Maoist policies associated with the Cultural Revolution. In 1981, the Party declared that the Cultural Revolution was 'responsible for the most severe setback and the heaviest losses suffered by the Party, the country, and the people since the founding of the People's Republic'.

situations.text:
Harry Potter is a series of fantasy novels written by British author J. K. Rowling. The novels chronicle the lives of a young wizard, Harry Potter, and his friends Hermione Granger and Ron Weasley. The main story arc concerns Harry's struggle against Lord Voldemort, a dark wizard who intends to become immortal, overthrow the wizard governing body known as the Ministry of Magic, involving wizards like Dumbledore and subjugate all wizards and Muggles (non-magical people).
Since the release of the first novel, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, on 26 June 1997, the books have found immense popularity, critical acclaim and commercial success worldwide. They have attracted a wide adult audience as well as younger readers and are often considered cornerstones of modern young adult literature. As of February 2018, the books have sold more than 500 million copies worldwide, making them the best-selling book series in history, and have been translated into eighty languages. The last four books consecutively set records as the fastest-selling books in history, with the final instalment selling roughly eleven million copies in the United States within twenty-four hours of its release.
The series was originally published in English by two major publishers, Bloomsbury in the United Kingdom and Scholastic Press in the United States. The final play, Harry Potter and the Cursed Child, was based on a story co-written by Rowling, and premiered in London on 30 July 2016 at the Palace Theatre, and its script was published by Little, Brown. The original seven books were adapted into an eight-part namesake film series by Warner Bros. Pictures, which is the third highest-grossing film series of all time as of February 2018. In 2016, the total value of the Harry Potter franchise was estimated at $25 billion, making Harry Potter one of the highest-grossing media franchises of all time.
A series of many genres, including fantasy, drama, coming of age, and the British school story (which includes elements of mystery, thriller, adventure, horror, and romance), the world of Harry Potter explores numerous themes and includes many cultural meanings and references. According to Rowling, the main theme is death. Other major themes in the series include prejudice, corruption, and madness.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Potter

situations.text:
The Lord of the Rings is a film series of three epic fantasy adventure films directed by Peter Jackson, based on the novel written by J. R. R. Tolkien. The films are subtitled The Fellowship of the Ring (2001), The Two Towers (2002) and The Return of the King (2003). Produced and distributed by New Line Cinema with the co-production of WingNut Films, it is an international venture between New Zealand and the United States. The films feature an ensemble cast including Elijah Wood, Ian McKellen, Liv Tyler, Viggo Mortensen, Sean Astin, Cate Blanchett, John Rhys-Davies, Christopher Lee, Billy Boyd, Dominic Monaghan, Orlando Bloom, Hugo Weaving, Andy Serkis and Sean Bean.
Set in the fictional world of Middle-earth, the films follow the hobbit Frodo Baggins as he and the Fellowship embark on a quest to destroy the One Ring, to ensure the destruction of its maker, the Dark Lord Sauron. The Fellowship eventually splits up and Frodo continues the quest with his loyal companion Sam and the treacherous Gollum. Meanwhile, Aragorn, heir in exile to the throne of Gondor, along with Legolas, Gimli, Merry, Pippin and the wizard Gandalf, unite to rally the Free Peoples of Middle-earth in the War of the Ring in order to aid Frodo by weakening Sauron's forces.
The three films were shot simultaneously and entirely in Jackson's native New Zealand from 11 October 1999 until 22 December 2000, with pick-up shots done from 2001 to 2004. It was one of the biggest and most ambitious film projects ever undertaken, with a budget of $281 million. An extended edition of each film was released on home video a year after its theatrical release.
The Lord of the Rings is widely regarded as one of the greatest and most influential film series ever made. It was a major financial success and is among the highest-grossing film series of all time with $3 billion in worldwide receipts. Each film was critically acclaimed and heavily awarded, winning 17 out of their 30 Academy Award nominations.

situations.text: Jenny is a farmer, and she has collected enough eggs from her chickens to send off to her buyer. She has a certain amount of eggs and cartons, but she can wait longer to get more eggs. She can put 4 eggs into each carton, but is left with 2 eggs left over. Alternatively, she can put 7 eggs into each carton, but she leaves half the cartons unused and also has 5 eggs leftover.

questions.text: How many more eggs, at a minimum, does she need to fill the cartons with 5 eggs each?
questions.explanation: The two simultaneous equations we can make are, for e = eggs and c = cartons: (1) e = 4c + 2, (2) e = 3.5c + 5. The reason equation (2) has 3.5c is because she leaves half the cartons unused, so essentially she puts 7 eggs in half the cartons, which mathematically looks like 7*(c/2), which we can simplify to 3.5c. Now we can just equate (1) and (2) and solve for c, so that 4c + 2 = 3.5c + 5, so that c = 6. Therefore by subbing c = 6 into (1), we know that she has 26 eggs. If she fills the cartons with 5 eggs each, that means she needs 30 eggs. Therefore, 30 – 26 = 4, she needs 4 more eggs. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text:
Two counters move along a line with 12 spaces as such, from the first to twelfth:
(1st space) _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ (12th space)
Both counters start on the first space. The first counter skips 1 space each time it moves. The second counter skips 2 spaces each time it moves. The second counter waits until the first counter moves once first, and then begins to move (ie. when the first counter is making it’s second move, the second counter is making its first move).

questions.text: How many spaces does the first counter skip before both of the counters meet on the same space?
questions.explanation:
If we draw a diagram, it may look something like this: _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
If we label each space from A to L (so 1st space = A), we get A-B-C-D-E-F-G-H-I-J-K-L. Both counters start on A. The first counter will go A, C, E, G, I, K, The second counter will go A, D, G, J. If we line these two orders up, offsetting the second counter by 1 space since it starts after the 1st counter, it will look like this:
A-C-E-G-I-K
A-D-G-J-
Therefore we can see on the 3rd space of the 2nd counter and 4th space of the 1st counter, they both meet at G. Therefore, the 1st counter has skipped 3 spaces. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

A sport academy has 3 sports, soccer, baseball and cricket. 40 players are sorted into 3 different classes, with some players being accidentally sorted into 2 of the sports.
2 players were put into both soccer and baseball.
Only 3 players were put into all 3 sports.
The number of players in baseball only and cricket only were the same.
The number of players in both baseball and cricket was 11.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be true?
options: There are more players in soccer than cricket
The number of players in soccer is 10
There are no players in cricket only
There are 7 players each in baseball only and cricket only
questions.explanation: We know from the first two statements that at least 5 players are in soccer. If we subtract the number of people in baseball and cricket, and these 5 players from the total of 40, we end up with a remaining 24. If 10 players are in soccer overall, then we know 21 players have to be in baseball and cricket combined (since we already accounted for the 5 soccer players in our previous calculation, we subtract only 5 from 24 instead of 10). This, however, is impossible as the number of players in baseball only is the same as the numbers in cricket only – and 21 is not an even number so it cannot be divided equally among those two sports. Thus we cannot have 10 players in soccer. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text:
Andrew, Ben, Carl and Daniel went to a dance competition and the received scores for their performances. Each competitor performed 2 different dances (scored individually and then added up overall). Individual scores given were only 0, 2, 3 or 6.
Ben scored the lowest of the four, but did not get 0 overall.

questions.text: If everyone scored different overall scores, what scores could Daniel have scored?
questions.explanation: Andrew could have scored a 3, 6, 9, or 12. If Carl scored the only 3, then Andrew could not have scored 3 or 9 (both scores require a 3 – eg. 3 = 0 + 3 and 9 = 6 + 3). Thus we know Andrew scored either a 6 or 12. If Daniel scored more than Ben but less than Andrew, we can take a look at the 4 options to see where he fits in. Option A is impossible as Carl got the only individual 3 score. Option D is impossible as Ben scored the lowest and did not get a 0 overall (meaning the lowest he could have got is a 2 overall), and thus we can then deduce that Option C is incorrect as well. That leaves us with only Option B, which can be a possibility if Ben scored a 2 (0+2) and Andrew scored a 6 or 12. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

1. Antidepressants increased from 54.2% to 66.9%, ADHD increased from 2.7% to 3.0%, Anxiolytics decreased from 17% to 11.4%. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. 300*0.17 = 51. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. We cannot calculate this as we do not know the total number of medications sold in 2000. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We don’t know the sales of Pharmacy C and cannot assume. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. Antidepressants in 2011 = 66.9%. Antidepressants + Sedatives in 2000 = 54.2% + 11.9% = 66.1%. They are only 0.7% apart. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

situations.text:
The following is a chart showing the population of countries in the European Union in 2007 by percentage.
Source: http://www.essaybuilder.net/PieCharts.html

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: There are a total of 27 countries in the EU
If the EU had 550 people in 2007, approximately 91 would be Germans
Poland is the smallest country in the EU
Germany has the greatest land size in the EU
Spain and Italy account for approximately 1/5 of the EU population in 2017.
questions.explanation:
1. There are 6 countries depicted + an ‘other’ category with 21 countries, so 21 + 6 = 27 countries. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. 550*0.166 = 91.3, and since we can’t create 0.7 people, we have to round down to 91 people. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. It may be the smallest of the 6 on the graph, but the 21 countries in the ‘other’ category could be smaller, we don’t know. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We do not know anything about land size from this graph, and we can’t make assumptions based on the population size. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. We do not know if this data remains true for 2017, as the graph is for 2007 only. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

situations.text: The following diagram shows the extracurricular activities a group of students participated in

questions.text: Which extracurricular activity had the most students?
questions.explanation: Volunteering = 40, Rowing = 22, Debating = 26, Tennis = 22, Dance = 19. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: At a sports carnival, there are two sports available for the fifty students who attended to play; cricket and soccer. Seventeen students chose to play both sports, but 2 more students chose to play cricket than soccer. If 19 students chose not to play any sports, how many students chose to play soccer?

questions.explanation: If 17 students chose to play both, and 19 chose none, that means 14 remain to play either one. If 2 more chose to play cricket than soccer, we can calculate the number for only soccer being (14-2)/2 = 6, and thus 8 played only cricket. Be careful however, the question asks for soccer overall, not just only soccer. Therefore 6 + 17 = 23. Thus, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: The diagram gives information regarding the subjects studied by students in a school

questions.text: What is the difference in the number of students that studied maths and the number of students that studied English and Science only?
questions.explanation: Number of students who studied maths = 73. Number of students who studied English and Science only = 17. Therefore the difference is 56. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text:
The type of phone of 115 students own are recorded.
60 students own a Samsung phone.
90 students own an iPhone
50 students own a Huawei phone
30 students own a Samsung phone, Huawei phone and an iPhone
20 students own a Samsung phone and an iPhone only
5 students only own a Samsung and Huawei phone

questions.text: The number of students that only own an iPhone cannot be:
questions.explanation: If 30 students own all three, and 20 own a ‘Samsung + iPhone’, then we know the categories of ‘only iPhone’ and ‘iPhone + Huawei’ have to equal 40 (90 – 30 – 20 = 40). However, if 5 students own a ‘Samsung + Huawei’, that means that the number of students that own ‘only Huawei’ and ‘iPhone + Huawei’ = 15 (50 – 30 – 5 = 15). Therefore, if at least 15 must be in the ‘iPhone + Huawei’ category (if ‘only Huawei’ = 0), then we know at least 25 must be in the ‘only iPhone’ category. Therefore, the correct answer is A, as it is impossible.

situations.text: Cars sold by a certain manufacturer has a combination of different technological features.

questions.text: Based on the diagram, which letter represents a car with satellite navigation and lane departure warning?
questions.explanation: Lane Departure Warning = arrow, and Satellite Navigation = circle, so the overlap between those two is F. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text:
George and Sarah are practising for the upcoming archery state championships. Sarah can hit the target 8 times out of 10, but George misses 2 times out of 10. When testing precision, Sarah can hit the same spot 15 times out of 60, whereas George can hit the same spot 18 out of 70.
Considering only the accuracy and precision, is George a better archer than Sarah?

options: Yes, George has higher accuracy and precision.
Yes, they both have the same accuracy, but George has higher precision.
No, Sarah has an 80% accuracy whereas George has 20% accuracy.
No, Sarah has a greater precision than George.
questions.explanation: Sarah has an 80% accuracy, George also has an 80% accuracy. Sarash has a 25% precision, George has a 25.7% precision. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text:
Jody has a box containing four blue rocks and five red rocks. She randomly draws one rock at a time and then replaces them into the bag.
The first three rocks are blue.Jody states that the probability the next rock is blue is 1/6. Is Jody correct?

options: Yes, because she has already drawn three blue rocks, meaning there is one blue ock out of six rocks that she has not drawn.
Yes, because since she has drawn blue rocks previously, there is a much higher chance of now drawing a red rock.
No, because there the probability of a red rock should be lower than 1/6 as there is almost an even number of each coloured rock.
No, because the probability of a blue rock is 4/9.
questions.explanation: Since she replaces the rocks, the fact that she took out the first three and they were blue has no bearing on the probability of the next rock being blue as well. Her probability of 1/6 would be correct if she was not replacing the rocks. Therefore, the correct answer is D, as there are still 4 blue rocks out of 9 in total.

situations.text:
Company Sanny Sunscreen makes sunscreen. The company conducted a survey at two different locations: Monnee Pond and Mulgrave. The only options of the survey are “happy” or “not happy” with the sunscreen. Of the customers that were asked to be involved in the surveys, some chose not to respond. When calculating “happy” rates, Sanny Sunscreen uses the total number of customers surveyed as the denominator.
There were 2100 people surveyed at Monnee Pond. 1500 said they were “happy”, and 100 chose not to respond.
There were 1000 people surveyed at Mulgrave. 200 said they were “not happy” and 200 chose not to respond.
The company is trying to decide in which centre they should invest more money. They will choose the centre that has the most “not happy” proportion of responses.
Should the Company invest at Monnee Pond instead of Mulgrave?

options: Yes, because the percentage of customers who were “happy” is higher at Mulgrave than Monnee Pond.
Yes, because more people responded to the survey at Monnee Pond than at Mulgrave.
No, because the percentage of customers who were “not happy” is highest at Mulgrave.
No, because the percentage of “not happy” customers is the same at both Mulgrave and Monnee Pond.
questions.explanation: At Monnee Pond, since 100 chose not to respond we can calculate that the number of ‘not happy’ responses is 500, resulting in a percentage of around 23.8% (500/2100). At Mulgrave, since 200 chose not to respond we can calculate that the number of ‘not happy’ responses is 600, resulting in a percentage of 60% (600/1000).  Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: Sally is playing a game, where she wants to roll three fours in a row to win the game. She gets three rolls to try. Her chances of rolling three fours in this turn is 1/216. Is this correct?

options: Yes, because rolling three fours in a row is very unlikely, and therefore the probability is very low.
Yes, because the chance of rolling a four is 1/6, so rolling three in a row is 1/6 x 1/6 x 1/6
No, because it is very unlikely that there will be three fours on her turn
No, because the probability is actually ½ from 1/6 + 1/6 + 1/6.
questions.explanation: Her chance of rolling 1 four in 1 roll is 1/6, so 1/6*1/6*1/6 = 1/216 for 3 fours in 3 rolls. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: Roger and Steven are playing a game. There is an equal chance of either of them winning a ‘mini game’ worth 1 point. They are playing to first to 5 points. Steven is leading 4-2. The probability that Roger wins overall is 1/8.

options: Yes, because since Roger is losing, the probability of him winning must be very low.
Yes, because the probability of Roger winning at any given time is ½, and he must win another three times.
No, because the probability of Roger winning is 1/6
No, because they have an equal chance of winning, therefore the probability that Roger wins overall is ½.
questions.explanation: For Roger to win, he needs to win 3 times consecutively as Steven is 1 win away from reaching 5 points. Thus, since the probability of Roger winning is 0.5, the probability of him winning 3 times consecutively is 0.5*0.5*0.5 = 0.125 = 1/8. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: The following graph shows the expenditure per student attending College X for several selected time period. The numbers reflect averages of the 2 years in each time category. The blue represents the expenditure in dollars not accounting for inflation, but the orange represents expenditure in those years accounting for inflation, so the value of money in the graph remains the same across all the time periods. Note that the value for 2002/03 for unadjusted dollars is the same as constant 2004/05 dollars (so 9.9).

questions.text: By what percentage has the average expenditure per student increased from 1982/83 to 2002/03 in unadjusted dollars, to the closest value?
questions.explanation: (9.9 – 3.2)/3.2 = 209.375% = 209%. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: If the average rate of increase in expenditure (unadjusted) between each time period on the graph across all the 6 time periods was the remain the same for the next time period of 2004/05, how much should the average total expenditure be in 2004/05, in thousands of dollars?
What is the value change in the worth of one thousand dollars in 2004/05 dollars from 1977/78 to 1982/83, to the closest dollar??
questions.explanation: In 1977/78, the value of money from 1977/78 value to 2004/05 value increased by 6.1/2 = 3.05 times. Therefore, $1,000 in 1977/78 would be 1,000*3.05 = $3,050 in 2004/05 dollars. In 1982/83, the value of money from 1982/83 value to 2004/05 value increased by 6.2/3.2 = 1.9375 times. Therefore, $1,000 in 1982/83 would be 1,000*1.9375 = $1,937.50. Therefore, the value change in the worth of $1,000 in 2004/05 value from 1977/78 to 1982/83 = $3,050 - $1,937.50 = $1,112.50. Rounded, the closest value is D – therefore the correct answer is D.

questions.text: What was the percentage change in the average expenditure in 2004/05 dollars from 1992/93 to 1997/98?
questions.explanation: (9.1 – 8.4)/8.4 * 100 = 8.3333…%. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: The following pie chart shows the distribution of trees across the world. Currently there are 50 million trees in Europe.

questions.text: How many trees are there in North America?
questions.explanation: If there are 50 million trees in Europe (27.8%), we can calculate that the total number of trees worldwide would = 50 million/0.278 = 179.856… million. Thus, North American trees = 179.856… * 0.486 = 87.41… million. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: If the number of trees in Australasia were to decrease by 10 million, what percentage of the world’s trees would Australasia then have, to the closest percentage below?
questions.explanation: If there are 50 million trees in Europe (27.8%), we can calculate that the total number of trees worldwide would = 50 million/0.278 = 179.856… million. Thus, Australasian trees = 179.856… * 0.167 = 30.035… million. Reduced by 10 million, this becomes 20.035… million. Therefore, 20.035…/169.856… = 0.1179… = 12%. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If the number of trees globally doubled, how would this affect the percentage distribution of trees in Europe?
options: It would be multiplied by four
questions.explanation: The percentages are unaffected if the overall number of trees are changes. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: If all the trees in the ‘rest of the world’ disappeared instantly, by how many trees approximately would Australasia have to plant/remove by if it were to maintain the same percentage value of global trees (to the closest value)?
questions.explanation: If there are 50 million trees in Europe (27.8%), we can calculate that the total number of trees worldwide would = 50 million/0.278 = 179.856… million. Therefore, the ‘rest of the world’ makes up 179.856…*0.069 = 12.41… million trees. Therefore, 179.856… - 12.41… = 167.44… million trees leftover. Thus, if we are to maintain 0.167*167.44… = 27.963… million trees for Australasia, we would need to remove 30.035… - 27.963… = 2.07… million trees (30.035… is from Q6 where we calculated the number of trees in Australasia). The closest answer is D. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

situations.text:
The following pie charts show number of apartment units sold to types of families.
Grey = Families with no children
Blue = Families with 1 child
Green = Families with 2 children
Black = Families with 3+ children

questions.text: What percentage of apartments were sold to families with 2 or more children in 2010?
questions.explanation: Green + Black = 2+2 = 4. Thus, 4/200 * 100 = 2%. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the closest ratio of apartments sold to childless families in 2010 compared to 1980?
questions.explanation: Childless 2010: Childless 1980 = 150:56 = 75:28. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: What proportion of apartments in 1980 were sold to families with only 1 child or families with no children?
questions.explanation: No child + 1 child = 56 + 30 = 86. Thus, 86/127 = 0.677… = 0.68. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the ratio of apartments sold to families with more than 2 children in 1980 to that in 2010?
questions.explanation: More than 2 children = Black. Ratio of 1980:2010 = 11:2. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: The following two pie charts show the distribution of annual spending in the average household in 2 different years. In 2010, the average annual household spending on food was $10,000.

questions.text: What did the average household spend on transportation in 2010?
questions.explanation: Total expenditure 2010 = 10,000/0.34 = $29,411.76… . Thus, expenditure on transportation = 0.14*29,411.76… = $4,117.647… = $4,118. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: How much more did the average household spend on education than healthcare in 2010?
questions.explanation: Total expenditure 2010 = 10,000/0.34 = $29,411.76… . The percentage difference between education and healthcare spending in 2010 = 6.3% - 4.5% = 1.8%. Thus, 0.018*29,411.76… = $529.41… = $529. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: If the average annual household spending on food doubled from 1950 to 2010, how much money did the average household spend on healthcare and transportation in 1950?
questions.explanation: We can deduce that the average household spending on food in 1950 would have been $5,000. Thus, the total household expenditure for 1950 is 5,000/0.112 = $44,642.857… . Thus, healthcare + transportation in 1950 = 2.4% + 3.3% = 5.7%. Thus, 0.057*44.642.857 = $2,544.64… = $2,545. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the closest ratio of average annual household spending on education in 1950 compared to 2010, if the total annual average household spending in 1950 was $7,000?
questions.explanation: Total expenditure 2010 = 10,000/0.34 = $29,411.76… . Education in 2010 = 0.063*$29,411.76… = $1,852.9… .Education in 1950 = 0.066*7,000 = $462. Thus, the ratio would for 1950 to 2010 would be 462:1,852.9 = 462/1,852.9 = 0.249… = 0.25. Thus, we can deduce that the closest ratio would be 1:4 (given that education spending in 1950 is close to 0.25 that of 2010). Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: The following graph shows the velocity of a car driving to and from a gas station in 30 seconds. At some points breaks were taken, where the car stopped. The units on the horizontal axis are in seconds. Note that velocity = displacement from start/time.

questions.text: How far is the car from the gas station 15 seconds after leaving?
questions.explanation: Since the velocity is 0, we can deduce that the car returned to the gas station as the displacement from start = 0. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: How far did the car travel between 4 seconds and 7 seconds (closest value)?
questions.explanation: Between the 2 dotted lines, the car travelled at a velocity of approximately 16m/s. Either way, whether you choose 15m/s or 16m/s if you multiply these values by 3 you get 45m and 49m, both of which are closest to 50m. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: For how long, to the closest value, was the car travelling away from the gas station?
questions.explanation: The car was travelling away from the gas station from 0-4 seconds, and from 15-23 seconds. Cumulatively, this is 4 + 8 = 12 seconds. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: If the car repeated its journey for another 30 seconds, for approximately how long was the car stationary in total?
questions.explanation: For this journey, the car was stationary from 27-30 seconds, so 3 seconds. If this journey was repeated again, that would make it 6 seconds. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

situations.text: The table below shows the annual number of Chemistry graduates from Cambridge University from 2007-2011. The total number of graduates from Cambridge was 5,000 in 2010.

questions.text: What percentage of the total graduates from Cambridge graduated in Chemistry in 2010?
questions.explanation: 1484/5000 * 100 = 29.68%. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: What was the average number of UK citizens graduating from Cambridge in Chemistry from 2007 to 2011, to the nearest whole student?
questions.explanation: Average = (704+789+764+761+731)/5 = 749.8 = 750 students. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: What proportion of Chemistry graduates in 2008 were from China, to 2 decimal places?
questions.explanation: 292/1548 = 0.1886… = 0.19. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What was the approximate percentage increase the number of non-UK citizens graduating from 2009 to 2010?
questions.explanation: 2009: 715 students. 2010: 723 students. Therefore, there is a difference of 8 students. Thus, 8/715 * 100 = 1.11…% = 1%. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: The following table shows the different sources of income and expenditure and further details of Company Y. Total revenue is calculated by adding gross sales and trading income together.

questions.text: If all the net income were distributed amongst employees equally, how much would each employee have gotten paid in euros in 2008?
questions.explanation: 2,656/63,358 = 0.0419205… million = 41,920.515 = 41,921 euros. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: What was the average total revenue in euros raised by the company from 2007-2009?
questions.explanation: Since the total revenue is adding gross sales and trading income, we can just add all 6 cells from 2007-2009 together and divide by 3 (instead of calculating the total revenue for each year first). Thus, average total revenue = (17,542 + 2,568 + 17,063 + 3,449 + 17,473 + 2,578)/3 = 20,224.33… million. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: By how much percentage-wise did the market capitalisation of the company decrease from 2008 to 2009?
questions.explanation: (59,759 – 45,609)/59,759 = 0.23678… = 24%. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What was the average rate of increase in long-term debt from 2007-2009?
questions.explanation: Increase from 2007-2008 = 2,583 – 2,507 = 76. Increase from 2008-2009 = 2,742 – 2,583 = 159. Thus, the average rate of increase = (76 + 159)/2 = 117.5 million/year. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

situations.text: Samantha was trying to lose weight and went to her doctor at the end of June to see what she could do. The doctor asked for her weight records for the first 6 months of the year. They are as below, measured at the end of the month.

questions.text: What was Samantha’s average rate of monthly weight gain?
questions.explanation: You could calculate the individual increases in each month, however a quicker way of doing this is just using the start and end values. In this case, we can find the average rate of increase by subtracting June from January and dividing by 5 (not 6, because there are 5 increases between 6 months, not 6). Thus: (80 – 49)/5 = 6.2kg/month. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What was the percentage increase in Samantha’s weight from February to May?
questions.explanation: Percentage increase = (73 – 54)/54 * 100 = 35.185…% = 35%. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If the doctor wants her to have lost 2 quarters of her weight by the end of the year, what should her average rate of monthly weight loss be?
questions.explanation: Her doctor wants her to lose essentially half her weight by the end of the year (2 quarters), which means she needs to lose 40kg (half of 80 is 40). Thus, over the next 6 months, she needs to lose an average of 40/6 = 6.666… = 6.67kg/month. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: If she puts on weight at a monthly rate of 3kg/month, how much weight would she have to lose in December alone (assuming she stops putting on weight at the end of November) if she wants to reach her weight loss goal of weighing 50kg?
questions.explanation: If the stops putting on weight in November, then she has been gaining 3kg/month for 5 months (July, August, September, October, November), so she has gained 15kg, bringing her to a total of 95kg. Thus, she needs to lose 45kg to reach her goal of 50kg by year’s end. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: A 5L water tank collects rainfall. If rain starts to fall on Monday at a constant rate of 10mm every 3 hours, on what day would the tank be first full?
questions.explanation: A 5L tank as 5,000mL, therefore it would take 5,000/10 = 500 sets of 3 hrs for the tank to get full. Therefore, it would take 1500 hours in total. To calculate the day: 1500/24 = 62.5 days = 8 weeks and 6.5 days. Therefore, 6.5 days after the start of Monday would be half-way during Sunday. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

situations.text: Harry, Roger and Jessica are competing in a 200m sprint race. Harry runs at a constant speed of 15km/h.

questions.text: If Roger runs twice has fast as Harry, how much quicker will he finish the race?
questions.explanation: If Harry takes t = d/s = 0.2/15 = 0.01333… hours = 48 seconds, and Roger runs twice as fast, that means Roger will take half as long, so 24 seconds. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: Jessica finishes the race 20 seconds before Harry. How fast was she running, assuming she kept a constant speed?
questions.explanation: If Harry finishes the race in 48 seconds (t = d/s = 0.2/15 = 0.01333… hours = 48 seconds), then Jessica takes 28 seconds = 0.0077777…hrs. Thus, s = d/t = 0.2/0.0077777… = 25.71…km/h = 25.7km/h. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If Harry ran the first 100m at 15km/h but slowed down in the last 100m to 5km/h, how much slower did he finish the race now that he did not keep up a consistent speed of 15km/h?
questions.explanation: First 100m = 24 seconds (since t = d/s = 0.2/15 = 0.01333… hours = 48 seconds from earlier questions, if it is half the distance it will take him half the time). Second 100m = d/s = 0.1/5 = 0.02hrs = 72 seconds. Therefore altogether, he takes 24+72 = 96 seconds. Since he takes 48 seconds at a consistent speed of 15km/h, we can calculate that he has taken an extra 48 seconds. Therefore, the correct answer is B.
