situations.text: A final year medical student, Lauren, is working at a hospital and hopes to gain clinical experience to aid her transition to a junior doctor. Lauren feels that the tasks assigned to her by her supervisor are not related to clinical skills. How appropriate are the following responses by Lauren?

questions.text: Complete the tasks without expressing her concerns to the supervisor
questions.explanation: This response offers no direct solution to Lauren’s concerns and displays a lack of willingness to communicate. It is not awful as it is not confrontational in manner and no immediately negative consequences will come about.

questions.text: Ask about other tasks (that are clinically related) that Lauren could undertake
questions.explanation: Although this is appropriate, it does not absolve her of the tasks she was asked to complete

questions.text: Ask advice from her tutor/academic adviser
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to seek clarification and advice from the relevant individuals. It will also provide an outlet for Lauren to voice her concerns

questions.text: Complain directly to the faculty about the supervisor
questions.explanation: It is best to resolve conflicts at a local level, by expressing the concerns to the supervisor or seeking advice first

questions.text: Not attend the placement and study clinical skills at home
questions.explanation: Not attending a placement is unacceptable unless the placement is voluntary or situations (such as health issues) prevent you from doing so – there is no reason to suggest this is the case in the scenario

situations.text: A medical student, Christopher, is observing a general practitioner. As the GP is taking notes about a patient, you notice that the GP notes his blood pressure as 160/80, despite you vaguely recalling the GP saying 120/80+. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Christopher in this situation?

questions.text: Inform the GP that you believe he may have incorrectly entered the patient’s blood pressure, once the patient has left the room
questions.explanation: If this is an error, it must be rectified as soon as possible and doing so after the patient has left the room is best – in case Christopher is mistaken and to not undermine patient trust in the GP

questions.text: Inform the GP that you believe he may have incorrectly entered the patient’s blood pressure, in front of the patient
questions.explanation: While this would help rectify the issue if an error has been made, Christopher should tell the GP in private to not undermine patient trust

questions.text: Quickly change the patients notes
questions.explanation: This is an inappropriate course of action that is not consistent with open and honest practice. Altering notes in this way is ground for gross professional misconduct.

questions.text: Ask the patient to clarify his answer to the question and explain why this is necessary
questions.explanation: While this would help rectify the issue if an error has been made, Christopher should tell the GP in private to not undermine patient trust

questions.text: When the GP is not around, tell the patient of the GP’s mistake
questions.explanation: Christopher may be in fact the one who misheard the patient. Telling the patient of the error will only serve to undermine the patient’s trust in the gp

situations.text: A university student, Jane, is the leader of a group project. Lee approaches Jane and complains about another student, Jill. Lee states that Jill has not been conducting research to an adequate standard and the other team members are struggling as a result. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Jane in this situation?

questions.text: Take no action unless another group member complains.
questions.explanation: This option is inappropriate as it does not recognise Lee’s observation. However, there are no drastically negative consequences that will arise from this

questions.text: Suggest that Lee speaks directly to Jane
questions.explanation: While such communication will be inevitably beneficial, it is the leader’s responsibility to take a more proactive approach in negotiating the scenario

questions.text: Report Jill to the tutor
questions.explanation: This option is inappropriate as Jane should first seek to resolve the conflict at a local level before escalating it and reporting Jill to the tutor. It is not very inappropriate as it would assist in resolving the issue

questions.text: Ask other group members about their thoughts on Jane’s contributions
questions.explanation: It is advisable for leaders to seek the opinions of other group members to gain an understanding of the views of all members

questions.text: Speak to Jill privately and raise the concerns
questions.explanation: The concern should be resolved at a local level with the individuals concerned. This will allow for open communication and a chance for Jane to defend herself

situations.text: A medical student organised a meeting with his mentor a number of weeks in advance. On the day of this meeting, a content revision session becomes available, however it is at the same time as the meeting. How important to take into consideration are the following factors for the student when considering how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: How important the mentor’s meeting is
questions.explanation: Whether the meeting can be rescheduled may depend on the importance of the meeting

questions.text: Whether the mentor can be contacted to reschedule the meeting
questions.explanation: The student should seek to ensure an open channel of communication with his supervisor. To not consider this would be unprofessional

questions.text: That there may be similar revision sessions that arise in the future
questions.explanation: If such a revision session is likely to present itself on another day, there may be no need to reschedule the meeting with the mentor

questions.text: His mentor’s view on the importance of this revision session
questions.explanation: While it is a good idea to take the mentor’s advice, the student must ultimately accept responsibility for choosing which sessions to attend and taking a proactive approach to her learning

situations.text: A dental student, Rajesh, is informed by a patient that a dentist frequently swears when interacting with patients and he finds it uncomfortable. Rajesh has not noticed this and, when he asks the dental assistant, she says that she has never heard the dentist swear. The dentist is marking Rajesh on his contributions to the dental clinic. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Rajesh when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The dentist is assessing him
questions.explanation: Although there may seem to be issues arising from this, the main focus should be the patient. Assessments must be marked objectively and so this is not an important consideration.

questions.text: A patient has informed him that he feels uncomfortable
questions.explanation: Patient safety and wellbeing should always be the utmost priority

questions.text: Other patients may also feel uncomfortable
questions.explanation: While this may be true, it is based on an assumption and so is not a very important consideration.

questions.text: The nurse has not witnessed the dentist swearing
questions.explanation: While this is important to take it into account, Rajesh has received a direct complaint from a patient and, regardless, this complaint needs to be followed up

questions.text: The dentist’s relationship with Rajesh
questions.explanation: The relationship between the student and the dentist is important to maintain and, hence, Rajesh must approach the issue carefully. Regardless however, this complaint needs to be followed up

situations.text: A medical student is sitting in a room with a patient. He will receive the results of his cancer biopsy today, but the doctor has not arrived yet. He is worried about what the results will show and his own morality. He asks the medical student what they think the results will show. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the medical student in this situation?

questions.text: Explain to the patient that he is unable to comment on what the tests will show as he is a medical student
questions.explanation: A medical student is not qualified to discuss the possible outcomes of the patient’s test nor what the future may hold for the patient. However, it is correct for a student to explain his role to the patient, so that the patient understands the student’s position. It would be more appropriate to empathetically acknowledge the patients concerns her

questions.text: Acknowledge the patient’s concerns and ask whether he would like them to be raised with the consultant
questions.explanation: It is essential to acknowledge patient concerns and, by asking whether to raise them with the consultant, the student will assure the patient that he is being heard

questions.text: Recommend that the patient asks his questions when the doctor arrives
questions.explanation: While this is not inappropriate, it does not display adequate empathy for the patient and his situation

questions.text: Tell the patient that he’ll be absolutely fine
questions.explanation: A medical student is not qualified to discuss the possible outcomes of the patient’s blood test nor what the future may hold for the patient. By telling the patient that he will be fine, the medical student would be unethically providing false reassurance

questions.text: Check the patient’s files online and tell the results to the patient as the doctor is running late
questions.explanation: Very inappropriate practice – medical students cannot check patient’s files or discuss the possible outcomes of the patient’s test

situations.text: Alexa is a medical student who shares a house a number of other medical students near the university. While the atmosphere was good initially, Karen, who was very friendly and amicable previously, has seemed very unhappy and irritable. She has also been skipping lessons recently and Alexa is worried that Karen might fail the upcoming exams. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Alexa when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That Karen’s behaviour might put others at risk
questions.Explanation: This is very important as Karen’s mental state might jeopardise both her welfare and the welfare of those around her

questions.text: That Karen may need space and Alexa shouldn’t interfere with her situation
questions.explanation: While Karen might want her own space, it is still a good idea for Alexa, as a friend, to ask Karen how she is coping

questions.text: That Karen might be having a difficult time and may need support and help
questions.explanation: As a friend, Alexa should seek to provide Karen with help and support. She might even need to suggest that Karen talk to others about her situation too

questions.text: If Karen fails her exams, she will have to resit the year
questions.explanation: While this is something to consider, the utmost priority should be Karen’s emotional wellbeing

questions.text: Whether exams can be deferred as a result of personal circumstances
questions.explanation: If Karen feels that she is not in an emotional state to sit the exams, due to personal difficulties, it is appropriate to ask the faculty whether deferred exams are a possibility

situations.text: Christina, a medical student, sees some liquid on the floor in the waiting room of a GP clinic. She is meant to be shadowing a GP but has arrived 10 minutes late to the practice and needs to meet up with the GP. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Christina to take when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The risk of infection that the liquid might pose to patients
questions.explanation: A very important consideration as patient safety should be the utmost priority. Additionally, in this environment, there may be immunocompromised patients

questions.text: The risk of patients and staff slipping on the liquidd
questions.explanation: A very important consideration as the safety of patients and staff should be the utmost priority.

questions.text: That it isn’t the job of the medical student to clean up the liquid
questions.explanation: Regardless of whose role it is, Christina should take a proactive approach in cleaning up the hazard

questions.text: That Christina is running late
questions.explanation: While doctors and medical students should strive to be punctual, the main issue here is the liquid and Christina should take the necessary steps in minimising this hazard.

questions.text: That the liquid is just water
questions.explanation: Regardless of the nature of the liquid, it should be cleaned up promptly. Even water would pose a significant slipping hazard for patients and staff

situations.text: In a university lecture, one student, Jamima, is chatting constantly with her friends and disrupting the class. Another student, Jeff, can see that this is disturbing lecturer but the lecturer is not telling off Jamima. Jeff is finding that these disruptions are affection his learning. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Jeff to take when responding to the situation?

questions.text: That his learning is being impacted
questions.explanation: The purpose of the lecture is for students to learn and any disruptions to this should be addressed

questions.text: That no other students have complained about Jamima as of yet
questions.explanation: While no other students have complained, this does not suggest that their learning has not been impacted by the disruptions. Taking action may benefit both Jeff and the other students

questions.text: How Jamima would feel if Jeff asked her not to make too much noise
questions.explanation: While Jeff should strive to be empathetic in his approach, Jamima’s potential feelings or response should not dissuade Jeff from vocalising his concerns

questions.text: That this content may be covered in a revision lecture again in the future
questions.explanation: Regardless of whether there is a possibility that the content will be repeated, Jeff should take action to ensure that his learning is not detrimentally impacted in this scenario

questions.text: If Jeff interrupts the lecture, the lecturer might not be happy and deduct marks for his assignment
questions.explanation: This this should not have an impact whatsoever on Jeff’s grades – the lecturer must mark assessments objectively and fairly and this should not be a disincentive for Jeff to raise a concern

situations.text: A medical student, Ben, is at a GP clinic and is observing a doctor. The doctor is very curt with patients and Ben notices that he is swaying side to side. Ben suspects that the doctor is intoxicated. How appropriate are the following responses by Ben in this scenario?

questions.text: Ignore the doctor’s behaviour
questions.explanation: If the doctor truly is intoxicated, patient welfare may be jeopardised; as such, Ben has an obligation to vocalise his concerns/take action

questions.text: Ask the doctor whether he has consumed alcohol
questions.explanation: While this may help Ben ascertain whether in fact the doctor is intoxicated, there is no way to know whether the doctor is telling the truth and, if the doctor has not consumed alcohol, this question may not be received well by the doctor

questions.text: Apologise to the patient for the doctor’s behaviour and state that you believe that he has consumed alcohol
questions.explanation: This will only undermine the patient’s trust in the doctor and it is based on an unvalidated assumption

questions.text: Express concerns to the relevant figure in the clinic (such as a senior doctor), in a private and timely manner
questions.explanation: Ben should express his concerns, as patient safety is at risk, and he should do so in a private, timely and non-confrontational manner

questions.text: Treat the patient himself using his medical knowledge as a student
questions.explanation: Medical students are not qualified to treat or provide advice to patients. They may only conduct minor procedures with the consent of the patient and under the supervision of a competent health professional

situations.text: Barney, a medical student, is at a hospital shadowing a Dr – Dr Gill. Dr Gill is writing a prescription for a drug that will be administered to the patient. Dr Gill then leaves the ward to attend to another patient. Barney reviews the notes, and it seems as though this patient is allergic to the drug administered. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Barney in this situation?

questions.text: Don’t act until Dr Gill returns to the ward tomorrow
questions.explanation: The situation is urgent and, if the drug is administered, the patient may have a severe adverse reaction. As such, acting fast is pivotal in this scenario

questions.text: Encourage the hospital to review the systems in place that allowed this error to occur
questions.explanation: While searching for the sources of errors is always important, the major concern here is the welfare of the patient. The reviewing process will occur after the situation has been immediately resolved

questions.text: Inform a different senior doctor on the ward about his concerns
questions.explanation: If the prescribing doctor is absent, it is very appropriate for the student to discuss his concerns with another doctor

questions.text: Send a message to the patient, from Dr Gill’s computer, recommending he take a different drug
questions.explanation: A medical student is not qualified to recommend courses of action to patients nor can Barney do so in Dr Gill’s name

questions.text: Do not take action as this drug only causes adverse reactions in rare circumstances
questions.explanation: Regardless, action should be taken promptly if the patient is allergic and the error must be reviewed

situations.text: A medical student, Lily, is watching a GP take notes when interacting with a patient. When asking the patient a question about their social history, you notice the GP tick ‘yes’ when the patient responded with ‘no’. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Lily in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the patient to repeat his answer
questions.explanation: This is a reasonable course of action as it may help the doctor rectify his error. However, it may also draw attention to his error in front of the patient

questions.text: Do not say anything as you may have misheard the patient
questions.explanation: If there may be a chance that the doctor has incorrectly entered information into the patient record, this should be dealt with and rectified

questions.text: Privately tell the doctor that you believe that he may have incorrectly recorded the patient’s response
questions.explanation: This is course of action will help rectify the doctor’s response without drawing attention to it in front of the patient

questions.text: Tell the patient that the doctor may have incorrectly recorded their response and ask that they repeat their response
questions.explanation: While this may help the doctor rectify his error, it will undoubtedly also draw attention to his error in front of the patient and degrade doctor-patient trust

questions.text: Alter the patient records when the patient isn’t in the room
questions.explanation: The patient records should only be changed by the GP and not the medical student alone under any circumstances

situations.text: An intern, Igor, is working at a hospital and receives a call from the oncology team saying that they are running behind. He now needs to tell his patient, Jim, that his treatment will have to be delayed until tomorrow. This will make no difference to his prognosis but he knows that Jim has been nervous about receiving the treatment. How appropriate are the following responses by Igor in this situation?

questions.text: Explain the reasons why his treatment will not happen today
questions.explanation: It is important to explain to Jim why his treatment has been delayed – particularly because he was anxious about it and deserves an explanation as to why things have changed.

questions.text: Ask Jim to ask any questions he might have to the treating team tomorrow as he doesn’t have time to answer them now
questions.explanation: As been very anxious about the treatment, prolonging it and not allowing him to freely ask questions beforehand is not good medical practice

questions.text: Ask a medical student to explain to Jim the reasons why his treatment is postponed until tomorrow
questions.explanation: Jim may have trust in Igor as his doctor and may prefer hearing the reasons from him. Additionally, it should be the responsibility of the doctor, not thrust upon a medical student, to complete this task

questions.text: Promise that he will try to negotiate with the treating team to get the treatment done today
questions.explanation: Igor cannot keep this promise and making such a promise is highly inappropriate. The treating team has already told Igor that this is not possible

questions.text: Tell Jim that postponing the treatment until tomorrow will not impact his prognosis
questions.explanation: We know that this is the case and telling him this may help allay his concerns, thus it is a highly appropriate course of action
